Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Anterior Out-of-Plane and In-Plane Techniques for Ultrasound-Guided Subclavian Vein Cannulation

Trial_Design.evidence: single-centre, open-label, randomised controlled trial included 128 patients

Participants.evidence: 128 patients undergoing elective surgeries requiring central venous access

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either the anterior out-of-plane or in-plane technique

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of a novel anterior out-of-plane technique compared to the conventional in-plane approach

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the first-pass success rate, assessed immediately post-procedure

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomised to either the anterior out-of-plane or in-plane technique using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the intervention

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 128 patients randomised, 126 were analysed

Result_Outcome.evidence: The first-pass success rate was significantly higher in the out-of-plane group (95%) compared to the in-plane group (77%) (p < 0.05)

Harms.evidence: Fewer complications, including arterial punctures (1 vs 5), were observed in the out-of-plane group
